docs.lead_paragraph: What seemed like a pipe dream only months ago now seems all but assured: the Federal Government will start running budget surpluses soon, perhaps even this year, leaving Congress and the White House with a windfall on their hands. As they begin debating what to do with it, they face three basic choices.

headline.main: Budget in the Black: A Dream Come True Proves to Be Somewhat Hard to Cope With

docs.abstract: Both parties in Congress and White House gear up for battle over what to do about budget surpluses that could develop as early as this year; have essentially three options: paying off national debt, cutting taxes and increasing spending for a number of popular and pet programs, each of which has its advocates; it remains to be seen whether any surpluses will be substantial enough for major initiatives of any type and whether the new fiscal flexibility can survive an economic downturn (M)
docs.snippet: What seemed like a pipe dream only months ago now seems all but assured: the Federal Government will start running budget surpluses soon, perhaps even this year, leaving Congress and the White House with a windfall on their hands.    As they begin...

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill that would sharply increase the penalties for fraudulent health insurance claims is in a position to be approved by both the Senate and the Assembly today in the last session of the Legislature before the new legislators are sworn in tomorrow. The bill is intended to reduce health and car insurance costs.

headline.main: Vote Expected Today On Anti-Fraud Measures

docs.abstract: Bill that would sharply increase the penalties for fraudulent health insurance claims is likely to be approved by both the New Jersey Senate and Assembly in last session before new legislators are sworn in (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Connecticut Department of Insurance will audit Oxford Health Plans in response to a request from a local medical association concerned about the health maintenance organization's financial problems. Oxford will be audited in the first quarter, in either February or March, said Sue Cogswell, an insurance department spokeswoman.

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Can free manicures and the lure of cold cash keep teen-age girls from getting pregnant? Gil Burnett, a retired trial judge from New Hanover County, N.C., thinks it's worth a try. Frustrated by 23 years of punishing crimes whose ''root cause,'' he says, was unwanted pregnancy, Burnett is pushing a plan called Project for Happier Lives, which would entice young women to stay un-pregnant through cash sweepstakes. Under it, any girl age 10 to 19 could enroll in three years of monthly classes in money management, career planning and (the crux) saying no to sexual advances, a subject Burnett has dubbed ''Games Guys Play 101.'' For staying un-pregnant, each girl would get the chance to win monthly drawings of $25 gifts (for hairdos and the like) and a $5,000 grand prize at the end of the year. Though the community has agreed that the program makes sense, there has been pointed opposition to the idea that society can buy good behavior. Burnett, who characterizes himself as a die-hard realist, argues that the plan is an unusual but reasonable technique for a county that had 200 teen-age pregnancies in 1996. At the moment, the county commission has stalled on whether to allow the health department to offer official support, but Burnett is steaming ahead with more than $15,000 in private financing and a vision of the project being replicated nationwide. Meanwhile, Burnett's supporters are not moved by the argument that purchased virtue is a vice.
docs.abstract: Gil Burnett, retired North Carolina judge, is pushing plan to encourage young women not to get pregnant by offering prizes in monthly cash sweepstakes; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations in the New York region are asking customers to pay larger -- in some cases much larger -- premiums this year after several years of holding down prices to spur enrollment in an area that long regarded managed care with suspicion. The increases, mirroring those by managed care companies around the nation, vary by plan and by who is covered. But even big employers, who are typically able to negotiate the cheapest rates, say they expect the first substantial increases in several years.

headline.main: H.M.O. Premiums Rising Sharply, Stoking Debate on Managed Care

docs.abstract: Health maintenance organizations in New York region are asking customers to pay larger premiums in 1998 after several years of holding down prices to spur enrollment in area that long regarded managed care with suspicion; health care experts predict that premiums will rise by 5 to 10 percent next year, prompting worries that managed care is no better at controlling costs than traditional indemnity insurance; analysts say managed care companies kept prices artificially low for years and are only now coming to terms with actual cost of care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S plan to broaden eligibility for Medicare ''sounded great'' to Nick Porto, a 62-year-old chemical plant technician in Donaldson, La., who took early retirement and a pension in October 1996. Mr. Porto pays $416 a month to stay in his company health plan. But he will lose that coverage after the 18th month, on March 31.
docs.abstract: Implications for early retirees and others of Pres Clinton's proposal to let people as young as age 55 buy into Medicare, Federal health insurance program now limited to those 65 or older, discussed; plan is likely to attract those with pre-existing medical problems that led private insurers to reject them or charge them high premiums; would be too expensive for many middle-aged Americans; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON officials have been planning to build an indoor swimming facility for more than a decade, but in a stunning turn of events two institutions it enlisted to share costs announced they will proceed -- without the municipality. Southampton College and Southampton Hospital will move ahead without the $2.5 million the town had promised to ante up for construction. The decision follows an often bitter debate pitting Town Supervisor Vincent Cannuscio against Town Board members. Further complicating the situation is the financial stability of Southampton Hospital. The hospital is almost $1 million in arrears to employee medical, pension and insurance benefit funds, nurses' union dues are also in arrears, and private vendors have complained of being owed money as well. The hospital says it is owed reimbursement money.

headline.main: Pool Project Is On, Sans Southampton

docs.lead_paragraph: The article (''The Hospitals of Tomorrow, Taking Shape Today . . . With New Networks a Major Factor,'' Dec. 28) quotes the president of the Connecticut Hospital Association: ''there is an element of provincialism in our towns -- nobody wants to see their local hospital go away.'' This theory should be extended to the state's Visiting Nurse Associations, which respected each others territories of operation for almost a hundred years in some cases.
